title: From heart surgeon bullying scandal , to patients sleeping on hospital floors , The Irish News looks back on the top health stories of 2025
body_text:
January - ‘Every winter it gets a little bit worse’
A flu spike and intense winter pressure on hospitals dominated the early weeks of 2025.
Criticised for not producing a winter health plan earlier the previous year, Health Minister Mike Nesbitt visited several hospital patients waiting long hours and challenged MLAs to do more than complain.
Hospital consultant Dr David Farren told the Irish News: “It’s been hectic, it’s been unprecedented. Every winter we think it can’t get much worse, but every winter it gets a little bit worse,” adding the health service was headed for “disaster” if flu levels continued to rise.
With the health service to receive over half of Stormont’s budget at £8.4bn, Mr Nesbitt said this was still not enough to balance the books and predicted a “deeply concerning” £400m shortfall caused by rising demand for services, pay and National Insurance costs.
Nurses spoke of the shocking conditions in hospital corridors, with one commenting: “I go home feeling like a terrible person.”
A Palestinian doctor working in Belfast shared his hope that “15 months of genocide” in Gaza would end, while resident doctors ended months of strikes by accepting a 4% pay increase.
From Nigeria to Coleraine, Dr Christian Oko also told the Irish News about how Irish missionaries inspired his career in medicine.
February - New children’s hospital in Belfast greenlit, at £450m over budget
New figures in February showed ‘a stampede for private healthcare’ in Northern Ireland, with around 6,000 patients going private for procedures like cataracts and hip replacements in 2024 - a figure that has trebled in five years.
Retired Co Derry GP, JP McCormack, said it was “disgraceful” that patients were being forced to use their life savings to avoid “dangerous waiting lists” and warned of a lack of aftercare.
Research from Queen’s University showed that young adults who had childhood cancers were being denied mortgages in their 30s, with calls for a right for their diagnosis to be forgotten to avoid lifelong financial discrimination.
The Health Minister said extending a Westminster Bill to Northern Ireland to curb smoking and vaping was “an opportunity to save lives,” while MLAs who supported a ban on puberty blockers were told they were not welcome at pride parades in Derry and the north coast.
A new children’s hospital in Belfast was finally greenlit at a cost of £671m. First supposed to open in 2020 at a cost of £223m, the price had shot up by nearly £450m.
There was also criticism that the Irish construction firm behind “the most expensive children’s hospital in the world” in Dublin had been awarded the contract along with another company.
Charities helping vulnerable people said they were “facing a cliff edge” after the Department of Health’s core grant funding scheme was cut in half from £3.6m to £1.8m.
In contrast, a £215m commitment to tackle waiting lists in the Executive’s Programme for Government was described as “a welcome surprise” by Mike Nesbitt.
March -Belfast woman’s ‘extreme guilt’ over being wrongly prescribed unsafe pregnancy medication
Belfast woman Susan Jamison (59) told the Irish News of the “extreme guilt” she felt after being prescribed unsafe medication during pregnancy, which caused her children to be born with disabilities.
Along with thousands of other families, she was wrongly told that sodium valproate was safe and described how a decades-long wait for compensation has added to her family’s suffering.
Figures obtained by the Irish News revealed that over 60 patients died in the care of mental health inpatient units in Northern Ireland over the last decade.
While a significant number were believed to be due to suicide, the figures also showed deaths related to other health issues.
April - Irish firm pulls out of contract to build new Children’s Hospital in Belfast
Stormont’s new budget for 2025/26 promised “to do things differently” with £215m to tackle hospital waiting lists and a boost for childcare.
Just weeks after being jointly awarded the contract to build the new £671m Children’s Hospital in Belfast was announced, BAM Ireland announced they were no longer taking part for commercial reasons.
Questions had been raised about their work on the National Children’s Hospital in Dublin, where costs had ballooned to €2.24bn.
Health chiefs admitted they still did not know the cause of potentially deadly bacteria in the water system of a long-delayed maternity hospital in Belfast, with MLAs questioning the Belfast Trust’s ability to manage major projects.
Northern Ireland’s annual medicine costs reached an all-time high of £875m, an increase of £280m in a decade, caused by the needs of an ageing population and effective but “highly expensive” new medicines.
May - Belfast Trust under pressure as heart surgeon bullying scandal revealed
Belfast Trust was shaken by claims of bullying among heart surgeons at the Royal Victoria Hospital, with an independent report stating that staff feared violence would break out among senior colleagues, that the tensions were putting patients at risk and some surgeons were even working from home.
Mike Nesbitt said the revelations “brought shame on our health service” and the “toxic culture” was unlikely to be an isolated incident across Northern Ireland hospitals.
Meanwhile, new figures highlighted that health workers in Northern Ireland suffered 90,000 physical attacks in the last decade - the equivalent of 25 attacks every single day.
A fear of having children taken away was said to be stopping mothers in Northern Ireland accessing mental health support, while a shortage of 400 foster carers was also highlighted.
Describing the joys and pressures of foster care, one family told the Irish News: “No child asks to be born into these circumstances… all they’re looking for is a chance."
Enniskillen woman Hazel Gray told the UK Covid Inquiry of her trauma at not being able to be with her parents George and Violet Little when they died, saying it was like they “disappeared”.
The head of the Northlands addiction treatment centre in Derry slammed a decision to cut £60,000 of Department of Health funding, saying that after 50 years of helping addict they should not have to “rattle a bucket every year” as drug and alcohol deaths increase.
As GPs voted overwhelmingly to reject a funding offer from the Department, Mike Nesbitt also revealed that a GP’s curiosity over a heart condition may have saved his life.
Health Minister Mike Nesbitt has credited a GP's "professional curiosity" with potentially saving his life by identifying a serious heart condition he was unaware of.
— The Irish News (@irish_news) May 19, 2025
Speaking about his personal experience, the minister said that Northern Ireland's health service will never… pic.twitter.com/RK6FFeOnZr
In an interview with the Irish News, the new Commissioner for Older People Siobhan Casey spoke about growing up as the youngest of 11 siblings and Northern Ireland’s “broken” social care system.
Newtownabbey GP, Dr Tracey Cruickshanks, told the Irish News that Mike Nesbitt was treating GPs like the “enemy” over his decision to impose a rejected contract offer, and the abuse being directed at her receptionists from patients having to call over 100 times to get an appointment.
'Mike Nesbitt spoke in Stormont as if we are the problem. We are the potential solution, if they would just see that and stop treating us like the enemy.'
— The Irish News (@irish_news) May 22, 2025
Dr. Tracey Cruickshanks said GPs are demoralised as Health Minister Mike Nesbitt forced through a rejected GP contract,… pic.twitter.com/s0bnktyD3n
Appearing before the UK Covid Inquiry, First Minister Michelle O’Neill downplayed the impact of her controversial attendance at the funeral of veteran republican Bobby Storey in June 2020, stating there was no evidence this caused a drop in Covid rules compliance.
Despite struggles over a projected £600m budget deficit, Mike Nesbitt announced that a further 26 emergency consultants would be hired in 2025 - paid for by a £30m reduced spend on locum doctors.
June - New £10m cross-border health fund
A new £10m cross-border health scheme was announced, allowing patients on waiting lists for more than two years to claim back money for private operations in the Republic.
Intended for procedures like hip and knee operations, this would later be extended to all European countries.
Part of multiple efforts to reduce waiting lists, there was some criticism from the BMA’s Dr Alan Stout who said it would favour those with the ability to pay upfront.
'It will favour those that can pay. And the second weakness which there's a significant amount of uncertainty about is the aftercare for patients'
— The Irish News (@irish_news) June 4, 2025
Belfast GP and Chair of BMA's Northern Ireland council Dr Alan Stout described Stormont's new £10m cross-border health fund as… pic.twitter.com/e51q9iryN9
An open letter from Co Derry GP John Diamond said that “disrespect” from the health minister was creating a push towards a private system, while west Belfast GP Michael McKenna told the Irish News that he hadn’t been able to take annual leave in five years.
THE BMA also accused the Department of Health of failing to protect its workforce through years of poor management, citing the GP dispute as well duty of candour proposals that could potentially criminalise health workers.
The front page of today’s Irish News. pic.twitter.com/Z6yk3wI8LZ
— The Irish News (@irish_news) June 26, 2025
Cancer patients in Northern Ireland were said to be facing a “ticking time bomb” for diagnosis and treatment over a chronic shortage of doctors.
Belfast Trust spent £30m on security in the last five years, nearly triple the cost of all other health trusts combined, with the Trust putting this down to the higher population in the city.
The Trust was also placed under the highest-possible level of intervention from the Department in June as the fallout from the allegations of bullying in the cardiac unit continued.
The frontpage of today’s Irish News pic.twitter.com/QE6fgK3mRe
— The Irish News (@irish_news) June 20, 2025
It emerged that nearly 5,000 NI patients had been referred to long Covid clinics since the pandemic.
North Belfast barber Jay Miller spoke about his miraculous recovery after a seizure left him in a coma for three weeks, while the former First Minister and DUP leader Peter Robinson also praised “the remarkable courage and tenacity” of his wife Iris as she battles cancer.
A Newry midwife was struck off over social media posts claiming that vaccinations “attacked babies” while in their mother’s womb, while international health workers were left “frightened and vulnerable” after racist rioting in Ballymena spread across Northern Ireland.
There was further criticism of an “absolutely absurd” arson campaign in west Belfast, with calls to tackle misinformation about the health risks of 5G masts.
Meanwhile, Northern Ireland’s Nurse of the Year Kelly Forbes told the Irish News about improving the mental health of stoic farmers and fishermen in rural Kilkeel.
July - Anger at Eleventh night bonfire beside hospital power supply
There was outrage as a Belfast bonfire appeared on a site with asbestos and next to an electrical substation that supplied both the Royal Victoria and Belfast City Hospitals.
Police declared it a major incident, but ultimately said it was too much of a security risk to step in and remove the material.
The chair of the Belfast Trust, Ciaran Mulgrew, was sacked on the orders of the health minister. Mr Mulgrew would later claim he was being made a scapegoat over the bullying allegations involving heart surgeons.
An Omagh athlete who lost the ability to walk as a child credited art therapy for helping him to recover and complete a 14-hour Ironman, while a Co Down father with motor neuron disease spoke of the “agony” of being denied lifesaving treatment over staff shortages.
The Western Trust was criticised over a “shambolic” consultation, as a public meeting on the contested future of the South West Acute Hospital was called off, with the health minister urging the trust to “restore confidence” from the public.
Over 1,400 looked-after children were reported missing since 2020, with the children’s commissioner telling the Irish News he was “profoundly concerned” due to the risk of criminal or sexual exploitation.
Senior surgeon, Professor Mark Taylor, was appointed in a new dedicated role to tackle Northern Ireland’s waiting lists and called them a “national shame.”
At the same time, the row between the health minister and GPs in Northern Ireland deepened as they announced they were taking “collective action” over their contracts.
August - Cancer deaths up 11% in a decade
A total of 45,000 people died from cancer in Northern Ireland between 2013-22, a rise of 11%, and representing 10 times the number of lives lost during the Troubles.
While much of this is due to an ageing population, the risk of dying from the disease also fell dramatically thanks to medical advances.
Former senator Máiríá Cahill told the Irish News about enduring a 49-hour wait in the Royal Victoria Hospital’s A&E Department, adding: “When a surgeon says to you ‘this is Northern Ireland, I am not a politician,’ you know you have a problem.”
In a platform piece for the Irish News, Dr Tom Black condemned the state of Northern Ireland’s health service, saying “we wouldn’t accept it for our pets” and “no one has a plan to fix it.”
Meanwhile, black market weight loss jabs being sold on social media pages like Instagram were putting people in hospital but with few prosecutions.
September - The surgeon with the saw
September began with an announcement that £215m of funding dedicated to reduce waiting lists was having an effect, with nearly 60,000 extra treatments, assessments and diagnostic tests.
With an estimated 500,000 people still on waiting lists, the health minister called it “early steps” but proof that “investment can change lives.”
Given the urgency, the new waiting list tsar put all subtlety aside when he appeared onstage with a rusty saw to to cut the “colossal” backlog down to size.
Speaking to the Irish News afterwards, Professor Mark Taylor said it was time to get tough on waiting list patients failing to show up for appointments with a “two strikes and you’re out” policy.
“That’s really harsh and not where we want to be. But I don’t know many people that don’t turn up on the day for an Oasis or a Bruce Springsteen concert, a football match or a final,” he said.
Red flag patients are supposed to be assessed within two weeks, and the woman told the Irish News the stress was “tearing her life apart.”
In May, a regional system was introduced to cut red flag breast cancer waiting times but the health minister admitted it was actually increasing waits for some because of funding shortfalls and missed chances for reform.
Northern Ireland’s Mental Health Champion, Professor Siobhan O’Neill, slammed the lack of progress in funding a 10-year mental health strategy despite a persistent rate of over 200 suicides a year.
A mother in west Belfast told the Irish News that long waits for mental health services had left her relying on food banks in order to afford private therapy for her son.
“Parents should not have to go without food in order to get the help that they need.”
— The Irish News (@irish_news) September 17, 2025
A west Belfast mother has said long waits for mental health services have left her relying on food banks to pay for her son’s therapy.
Read her story: https://t.co/GGfgmWSlsl pic.twitter.com/WIcPrpcy6T
An annual health inequalities report also found that drug deaths were “six times more likely” in Northern Ireland’s most deprived areas, with healthy life expectancy also 14 years lower.
West Belfast GP, Michael McKenna, said that after years of alcohol causing the most problems there was now an endemic level of drug use in his area.
An IT crisis in the Southern Trust caused major disruption including cancelled operations, with officials later ruling out a cyber attack.
The cross-border reimbursement scheme was extended to Europe, with patients now eligible to apply after one year.
Autism NI spoke out against US President Donald Trump’s unfounded claims that paracetamol was causing a rise in autism, with the charity stating that improved diagnosis and a better understanding of the condition was far more likely.
It was also reported that Northern Ireland’s health trusts spent £185m on negligence pay outs between 2010/11and 2024/25, while MLAs shared their anger that women were waiting nearly 10 years for a diagnosis of endometriosis, a condition that “tears lives apart.”
Virginia Hardy (95) from Strangford also asked: “what’s the point in being in a coffin?” as it emerged that a 1,000 people in Northern Ireland have signed up to donate their body for scientific research at Queen’s University after their deaths.
October - Bullying report highlights ‘ongoing risk to patients’ in Belfast Trust
A report into bullying in the Belfast Trust found there was still an “ongoing risk to patients” due to “little trust” between some heart surgeons, with measures in place to address the problems including “civility training.”
The report authors later said they would be content for a relative to receive treatment in the cardiac unit, but a failure to address the serious relationship problems could lead to more problems in the future.
Mike Nesbitt detailed his efforts to tackle “unacceptable” cancer waiting times, warned against the use of “unauthorised” puberty blockers and said that significant progress in health reform would likely be a task for his successor.
He also shared his “personal disappointment” that a lack of funding meant 80% of Northern Ireland’s Mental Health Strategy was being shelved, with just £12m on the £1.2bn 10-year plan so far.
After nurses warned of “imminent strike action,” it was hoped a last-minute cash boot from the Executive would be enough to avert crisis.
An anonymous letter from a burnt out A&E nurse in Antrim Area Hospital described one day on the wards, which she described as like “a war zone” where staff fight to treat overwhelming numbers of sick and elderly patients.
In the South West Acute Hospital, Omagh woman Kerry O’Neill (44) also shared a tearful video from the floor of the South West Acute Hospital as the health minister defended his winter-preparedness plan.
Autism NI said that with more than 17,000 children on a waiting list for assessment, parents were being forced to pay for a private diagnosis.
This weekend's front cover of The Irish News pic.twitter.com/vFgYlS0DeH
— The Irish News (@irish_news) October 11, 2025
Breastfeeding experts told the Irish News how “manipulative marketing” from formula companies and health inequalities were creating barriers for mothers and why it can still be such a difficult subject to talk about.
Alliance MLA and cancer survivor Stewart Dickson raised concerns that EU rules were stopping Northern Ireland from taking part in a potentially lifesaving UK clinical trial.
The “sponge on a string” test can indicate if a patient is more likely to develop oesophageal cancer, but the Belfast Trust was left waiting for permission to start for over a year.
Record numbers of children in care in Northern Ireland, 4,188, were described as showing a system “beyond breaking point,” while the health minister halted the introduction of a controversial new Public Health Bill over “human rights concerns.”
A consultation into the bill had sparked fears over issues like mandatory vaccinations in a public health emergency, which the health minister had denied would happen.
November - Cancer patient left on hospital floor for two days
First highlighted by the Irish News, the health minister apologised for the care given to cancer patient Ernie Irvine who lay on the floor of Altnagelvin Hospital for two days.
Health minister Mike Nesbitt has apologised for the care received by a stage 4 cancer patient who was treated on the floor for more than two days at Altnagelvin Hospital.
— The Irish News (@irish_news) November 20, 2025
Ernie Irvine, 55, spoke to The Irish News this week about the “turmoil” he witnessed in the emergency… pic.twitter.com/tFEehP4rIJ
The health minister was accused of “failing women” over the Southern Trust’s cervical screening scandal, during which 17,500 women were told their smear tests needed to be reviewed.
After a new report, campaigners from the Ladies with Letters group maintained they would only be satisfied by a public inquiry.
As the General Medical Council warned that half of new doctors were leaving Northern Ireland after five years, the Executive approved the £200m needed for pay awards but at a cost to next year’s budget.
Police issued an update into probe into Dr Michael Watt, the ex-consultant neurologist in Belfast that triggered Northern Ireland’s largest ever patient recall, stating it was gathering pace but would likely still take years to resolve.
The Western Trust was also accused of having already made it’s mind up to permanently remove emergency general surgery from the South West Acute Hospital, with campaigners highlighting the case of Fermanagh man Mark McGuigan (61) who had to wait for three days in Altnagelvin’s A&E in the months before his death.
Today's front page of The Irish News pic.twitter.com/yr4d2DoyUp
— The Irish News (@irish_news) November 28, 2025
Meanwhile, two Irish-funded mobile maternity units remained stuck in a Cairo warehouse as women in Gaza give birth in “horrendous conditions.”
December - ‘Cheaper than a cup of coffee’ - Belfast man says low cost cider destroyed his health
Flu cases in Northern Ireland trebled in two weeks by the start of December, with the health minister warning the early spike has “hit us extremely hard.”
Health charities called on Stormont to urgently introduce minimum unit pricing for alcohol.
Supporting the appeal, recovering Belfast addict Paul Wilson described how paying £3 for two litres of 7.5% cider destroyed his health.
Three of the Executive parties support the change, with only the DUP yet to support it over what they say is a lack of evidence.
After Portadown man Jay Woolsey (33) died after buying highly dangerous drugs on the dark web, his mother told the Irish News how the grief “hit like a freight train.”
Mike Nesbitt said he had “no ideological objection” to increased cross-border health services, while new figures showed that over 500 patients were stuck in hospitals despite being medically fit to go home.
The Northern Trust also defended the safety record of moving all births to Antrim Area Hospital, despite campaigners warning of a “surge” in red escalation alerts.
